newsitem.title: GERMANY: SOCCER-BAYER LEVERKUSEN MISS OUT ON VITAL POINTS.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-BAYER LEVERKUSEN MISS OUT ON VITAL POINTS.

text.p: Bayer Leverkusen missed a chance to catch Bundesliga leaders Bayern Munich on Saturday when they allowed hosts Borussia Moenchengladbach to snatch a 2-2 draw with a last-minute goal.

Leverkusen, who are now two points behind Bayern, stormed ahead in the first half with a goal after just 45 seconds by Niko Kovac and another headed in by German international Ulf Kirsten just before half-time.
But Leverkusen could not hold on to their lead, letting in Jorgen Pettersson in the 65th minute and fellow Swede Martin Dahlin just before full-time.
Bayern have a chance to build a five-point cushion between themselves and Leverkusen when they face local rivals 1860 Munich at the Olympic Stadium on Sunday.
1860 will struggle to do Leverkusen any favours in their title chase. They have not defeated Bayern since 1977.

"The 2-2 draw could be decisive for the championship," Leverkusen coach Christoph Daum said. "After the first goal we controlled the game and had enough chances for a 3-0 win but Moenchengladbach got going after the break."
Bayer have four more league matches this season.
At least Leverkusen striker Kirsten could console himself with his 18th goal of the season, making him joint top scorer with VfB Stuttgart striker Fredi Bobic.

Third-placed Stuttgart, meanwhile, narrowed the gap between themselves and Leverkusen to two points and booked themselves a place in the UEFA Cup with a 3-0 rout of relegation-bound St Pauli, who were reduced to nine men by the 68th minute.
Stuttgart, without Bobic who sustained a head injury in Germany's World Cup qualifier against Ukraine on Wednesday, were held goalless in the first half.
Andreas Buck ended Stuttgart's frustration in the 54th minute. Bulgarian Krasimir Balakov added the second, followed by Bayern-bound Brazilian Giovane Elber, who scored his 17th this season.
"That was no easy game against a very defensive opponent. Before the change we missed out on going ahead. But by the end we had an easy game," said coach Joachim Loew.
Champions Borussia Dortmund stayed in fourth place with a 1-0 victory over Schalke, who meet Inter Milan in next week's UEFA Cup final first leg.
Bottom of the table Freiburg regained some dignity with a 2-0 victory over Duisburg and Hamburg pulled away from the relegation zone with a 3-2 win over mid-table Werder Bremen.
